metadata.title: Unparalleled dimerization of <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-2-butene to 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene on iron-based catalyst

Unparalleled dimerization of trans-2-butene to 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene on iron-based catalyst Kang Gao Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Data curation Conceptualization a Guangjing Feng Visualization Methodology a d Chaoan Liang Validation Software Methodology a Zhuang Wang Validation Software Methodology b c Xiaoyan Sun Writing – review & editing Supervision b c Jianhua Liu Validation Formal analysis a ⁎ Chungu Xia Validation Supervision a Yuxiao Ding Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou 730000 China State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, China b Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 266101 Qingdao, China Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology Chinese Academy of Sciences Qingdao 266101 China Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 266101 Qingdao, China c Shandong Energy Institute, Qingdao 266101, China Shandong Energy Institute Qingdao 266101 China Shandong Energy Institute, Qingdao 266101, China d University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Trans-2-butene is regularly burned as a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) component in several developing countries due to its inertness and inseparability in comparison to other butene isomers (1-butene and isobutene), resulting in low-value utilization of resource and environmental degradation. The generation of high-carbon olefins via trans-2-butene oligomerization has become one of the most effective ways for its high-value valorization. Octene is currently undersupplied via ethylene oligomerization, and its traditional crafts are costly due to separation from full-fraction α-olefins (C4-C30). In the present work, we synthesized a series of novel 2-phenyl-ketimine-1,10-phenanthroline iron complexes (Fe0-Fe9). Fe2 catalyst realizes the dimerization of trans-2-butene through homogeneous catalysis at moderate conditions (0.2 MPa, 30 °C), obtaining 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene with 99.9 % selectivity. In contrast to the reported heterogeneous catalysts, our catalytic system exhibits a considerable improvement in activity and selectivity. Keywords Methyl modulation 2-Phenyl-ketimine-1 10-Phenanthroline Homogeneous catalysis 99.9 % Selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Octenes (C8H16) are frequently utilized in industry, such as in the manufacture of polyolefin or polyolefin elastomer (POE), adhesives, special detergents, flavors (food), gasoline additives, synthetic lubricating oils, and more. Most of the currently commercialized C8H16 is mainly separated from full-fraction α-olefins resulting from ethylene oligomerization (e.g., shell higher olefin process, SHOP), which cannot only meet a variety of downstream markets because of finite capacity, but also increase the economic cost of industrial techniques [1]. Owing to the growing demand for C8H16 in recent years, the selectivity technology of producing α-olefins with specific carbon numbers has also received attention [2]. In light of the unsatisfactory performance (low yield) of ethylene selective oligomerization to octene, as well as their byproduct polymers resulting in clog lines, innovations from route source transition to butene dimerization as the most promising strategy. In comparison to ethylene tetramerization, the process of butene dimerization to C8H16 is more efficient due to shorter oligomerization steps [3–7]. Among isomers, the dimerization of trans-2-butene is interesting since branched dimers (3,4-dimethyl hexene) can be formed, which is a highly important chemical feedstock employed in the field of rubber and flavor precursors (food). Its polymerization products have good elasticity and abrasion resistance, and when copolymerized with other monomers, it can also adjust the polymer's glass transition temperature, hardness, and other properties, which are used to produce high-performance rubber products. Within the last two decades, the progress in trans-2-butene oligomerization has been slow, and most efforts were made on heterogeneous catalysis [8–15]. Fig. 1 depicts the traditional synthesis strategy. The main difficulty is to accurately control the selectivity of the reaction and to obtain a high yield of desired dimeric products. The formation of by-products (other oligomers) resulting from the multiple active sites in heterocatalysis not only decreases the purity of octenes but also increases the cost of following separation. Compared with heterogeneous catalysts, there are considerable advantages to homogeneous catalysts, such as a single active site, high selectivity, and non-separation processes for products. In the present communication, we synthesized a novel single active site catalyst (2-imino-1,10-phenanthroline iron (II) complexes) via facile ketamine condensation to regulate trans-2-butene dimerization, in which the complex Fe2 exhibits unprecedented 99.9 % selectivity to 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene. Our contribution not only paves the way for the high valorization of trans-2-butene (it is normally burned as a raw material for liquefied petroleum gas, resulting in resource waste), but also provides a novel and comparable route for the high selectivity synthesis of 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene in comparison with published work [16,17] (Fig. S1). In addition, the speculation that unfavorable insertion of trans-2-butene into metal sec-butyl fragments [11] is reversed by the present system. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 1, 10-Phenanthroline (99 %), p-toluenesulfonic acid (98.5 %), iron(II) chloride tetrahydrate (98 %) and all aniline derivatives (methyl- and dimethyl-substituted at 99 % purity) were obtained from Aldrich and used as received. Subsequently, toluene and tetrahydrofuran (THF) were subjected to reflux over sodium-benzophenone under nitrogen atmosphere until the solution displayed a blue coloration, after which the mixture was distilled prior to use. Furthermore, methylaluminoxane (MAO, 1.5 M in toluene) and benzyllithium (1.2 M in hexane) were sourced from Akzo Nobel Corporation and Albemarle Corporation, respectively, and were maintained under an inert atmosphere. All other chemicals, high-purity alkenes, and deionized water were commercially acquired and employed without any further purification unless otherwise specified. 2.2 Synthesis of catalyst The synthesis of 2-benzoyl-1, 10-phenanthroline was carried out based on the previously published patent with reference to Fig. 2 a [18]. A total of 4.5 g of 1, 10-phenanthroline was added into a 250 mL three-necked flask, which was dissolved in 100 mL of toluene under nitrogen and magnetic stirring. Subsequently, 60 mL of the hexane solution (1.2 M) of benzyllithium (0.07 mmol) is added slowly and dropwise into the three-necked flask, where it was stirred at −60 °C for approximately 10 min. The stirring is continued at −60 °C for 18 h, after which 50 mL of distilled water is added slowly. Thereafter, the temperature was raised to 30 °C, and the stirring was continued for 10 h. Afterward, the mixture was separated, wherein the organic phase was separated, and the inorganic phase was extracted by 20 mL dichloromethane for 3 times. The organic phases were then combined, and the solvent in the combined organic phase was removed under reduced pressure. Subsequently, 50 mL of nitrobenzene (1.205 g⋅mL−1) is added, and the mixture is then refluxed at 200 °C for 50 h. Following filtration, nitrobenzene is removed via rotary evaporator, resulting in the isolation of a black, viscous liquid substance. The mixture of ethyl acetate and petroleum ether at a volume ratio of 1:2 is then employed as an eluent in a silica gel column chromatography procedure on the black viscous liquid substance, and a brown product weighing 1.5 g and yielding 33 % was obtained. The identity of this product was confirmed through nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), element analyzer (EA), and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) analyses, leading to its identification as 2-benzoyl-1,10-phenanthroline (L0). Shown in Fig. 2b, a mixture comprising 2-benzoyl-1, 10-phenanthroline (0.57 g, 2.00 mmol), five equivalent aniline derivatives (Ph, 2-MePh, 3-MePh, 4-MePh, 2,3-MePh, 2,4-MePh, 2,6-MePh, 3,4-MePh, and 3,5-Me2Ph), and p-toluenesulfonic acid (0.15 g) were prepared in a 100 mL two-necked flask fitted with a condenser and a water knockout trap, utilizing 15 mL of toluene as the solvent. The reaction mixture was subjected to stirring and heated under N2 atmosphere at 120–150 °C for a duration of 12 h. Subsequently, the toluene solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the resulting solid was purified via column chromatography on alumina using a petroleum ether/ethyl acetate solvent system (v/v = 5:1). The third fraction obtained from the elution process was collected and concentrated, yielding a yellow solid in the following respective yields: 32 % for L1 (2-benzoyl-1,10-phenanthroline aniline), 45 % for L2 (2-benzoyl-1,10-phenanthroline 2-methyl aniline), 2 % for L6 (2-benzoyl-1,10-phenanthroline 2,4-dimethyl aniline), 68 % for L7 (2-benzoyl-1,10-phenanthroline 2,6-dimethyl aniline), and 2.2 % for L9 (2-benzoyl-1,10-phenanthroline 3,5-dimethyl aniline). In the context of complexes synthesis, the ligands (L0, L1, L2, L6, L7, and L9) and 0.9 equiv. of FeCl2·4H2O were co-added into Schleck tube that had been purged three times with nitrogen and subsequently charged with deaerated THF. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 6 h under a N2 atmosphere, resulting in the formation of a brown or blue precipitate. The obtained precipitate was then filtered and washed with diethyl ether (3 × 20 mL), and dried under reduced pressure. All iron (II) complexes were synthesized with high yields using this approach. One-pot synthesis was used for complexes without ligands obtained (L3, L4, L5, and L8). These complexes were isolated as dark brown powders with yields of 99 % (Fe0), 46.6 % (Fe1), 86.4 % (Fe2), 95 % (Fe3), 96 % (Fe4), 95 % (Fe5), 87 % (Fe6), 88 % (Fe7), 95 % (Fe8), and 95 % (Fe9). 2.3 Characterization Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded at room temperature using a Bruker DMX 400 MHz and 600 MHz instrument, with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard. Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained via a PerkinElmer System 200 spectrometer. While gas chromatography (GC) analyses were conducted on an Agilent 7890 instrument, featuring a flame ionization detector and an HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm (i.d.), 0.25 µ). High-resolution mass spectra (HR-MS) were captured in the electron impact (EI) mode on an Agilent 6890 mass spectrometer. Structural analysis of iron (II) complexes was performed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) data collected with a Bruker CCD X8 Kappa APEX II diffractometer, employing Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystal structure was solved using direct methods in Olex2 and refined through the SHELXL program, where anisotropic displacement parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms, and hydrogen atoms were refined as riding atoms. 2.4 Oligomerization All reagents were transferred into the reactor under nitrogen atmosphere through standard Schlenk techniques. The oligomerizations of alkenes were performed in a 250 mL stainless steel autoclave, which was equipped with a gas pressure control system, a mechanical stirrer, and a temperature controller. The autoclave underwent three cycles of evacuation and refilled with nitrogen to ensure an inert environment. Subsequently, toluene (80 mL), a solution of the pre-catalyst (Fe0-Fe9, 5 μmol) in toluene (20 mL), and the requisite amount of co-catalyst (MAO) with a Al/Fe ratio of 1500, were successively introduced via syringe under an alkene atmosphere, resulting in a total solvent volume of 100 mL. Once the desired temperature of 30 °C was reached, stirring commenced and the alkene pressure was raised to the target level, maintained through a continuous feed of the corresponding alkene precursor. After 30 min reaction, the process was terminated by cooling the reactor in an ice bath, followed by a gradual release of excess pressure. Approximately 1 mL cooled reaction solution was taken and 5 % aqueous hydrogen chloride was added to quench the reaction, of which 0.1 µL was then promptly injected into the GC instrument for the determination of oligomer distribution. The mass fraction of α-olefins was calculated based on the ratio of the corresponding peaks to the internal standard peak (n-dodecane) observed in the GC. The catalytic activity and selectivity were assessed based on the mass of all oligomers fractions obtained. 3 Results and discussion In light of superior catalytic performance of 2-imino-1,10-phenanthroline iron (II), nickel (II), or chromium (III) complexes in ethylene oligomerization [19–23], we synthesized analogous derivatives and conducted originally their catalytic behaviour in 2-butene oligomerization. The synthesized compounds were characterized and confirmed by the analysis of FT-IR, NMR, MS, and XRD characterization, of which their results were stated in the Supplementary File. As displayed in Fig. 3 a, Fe2 catalyst with mono-methyl ortho-substitution intriguingly demonstrates catalytic activity of 5.27 × 104 g⋅mo l Fe -1 ⋅h−1, whereas the others (Fe0, Fe1, and Fe7) show no reactivity at otherwise identical reaction conditions. In addition, only the 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene product of butene dimer was determined through GC–MS and NMR characteristics. This result might be attributed to the synergism of electronic and geometric effects because methyl belongs to the minor steric hindrance and electron-donating group. The Fe2 complex was more favorable for the adsorption coupling of butene π bonds at the fitting position as a result of the electronic contribution of monomethyl to the centrally active metal. However, the Fe1 catalyst lacks the ability to coordinate with 2-butene because it possesses insufficient electron density and thus shows empty activity. Moreover, Fe7 equipped with dual methyl ortho-substitution, results in a more difficult insertion of the 2-butene due to the larger steric hindrance in comparison with that of the Fe2 complex. In order to provide more experimental evidence to verify our speculations, we also synthesized a series of catalysts with mono/dual methyl substituted at different positions (Fe2-Fe9) on aryl imine for the catalysis of 2-butene, and the results are shown in Fig. 3b. The complex with the monomethyl group on arylimine ring shows butene oligomerization activity regardless of methyl position (Fe2-Fe4), consistent with the fact that the methyl group provides electrons to promote the central metal to be able to adsorb the butene molecule. Meanwhile, the variance in the dimerization activity of trans-2-butene (ortho- > para- > meta-) is attributed to the difference in the ability of the methyl group to induce and synergistic conjugate effects (electronic and steric hindrance) at different positions. In addition, we found in the results of bis-methyl substitution that the Fe(II) complexes are catalytically active as long as the substitution of the methyl group in the double neighboring position is avoided at the same time (Fe5, Fe6, Fe8, and Fe9). The catalytic system comprising Fe2/MAO was systematically evaluated under a variety of reaction conditions, including catalytic residence durations (Fig. 4 a) and reaction temperature, as well as molar ratio of Al/Fe (Fig. 4b). As depicted in Fig. 4, optimal reactivity was achieved at a temperature of 30 °C with a reaction duration of 30 min along with Al/Fe of 1500. A decrease in the catalytic activity (Fig. 4a) is observed upon increasing either reaction temperature or duration, however, the selectivity of C8H16 was maintained regardless of the designed conditions. This constancy in selectivity is likely attributed to the deactivation of the catalytic species, which in turn precipitates a swift diminution in the metal-hydride intermediate. A comparable outcome has been documented in the literature for bis(imino)pyridine precursors [24]. Such deactivation was also observed for other 2-imino-1,10-phenanthroline iron(II) catalyst precursors. When the reactions were conducted at 50 °C, more than half of the activity was observed, confirming that the iron complexes herein employed are thermally sensitive. In addition, the effect of the Al/Fe molar ratio on trans-2-butene oligomerization was also investigated with the Fe2 complex. With an Al/Fe molar ratio of 1500, the catalytic activity peaked (Fig. 4b), however, the higher ratio of Al/Fe did not result in higher activity. In-situ ESI-MS characterization was conducted to further interpret the difference oligomerization between the synthesized Fe(0–9) complexes. The crucial reason that no dimeric activity (products) detected over Fe0 catalyst should be attributed to the absence of the active cationic intermediate LFe(CH3)+. It was not formed when cocatalyst MAO was added into the Fe0 complex, followed by alkylation and ionization. The analogous results were also found in the ethylene and propylene oligomerization (Fig. S2). In contrast to the Fe0 catalyst, LFe(CH3)+ could be found in the activation of the Fe1 complex by MAO, however, the intermediate species metal sec-butyl fragments (8) were not observed due to the insufficient electron density, leading to the failure of coordination of butene with metal-hydride species (4) (Fig. 5 ). Although the intermediates (2) and (8) were found in the Fe7 complex, the unfavorable insertion of second trans-2-butenes into metal sec-butyl fragments results in the termination of oligomerization because of the bulky steric hindrance. To the best our knowledge, the activity of terminal/vinyl alkene is generally higher than that of internal alkenes in polymerization reaction. In addition, all isomers of butene monomer (1-butene, (Z/E)-2-butene, isobutene) were also applied in the alkene oligomerization on Fe2 catalyst under the same condition (Fig. S3). Interesting fact, besides dimerization activity observed for trans-2-butene monomer, is that no oligomerization product was determined in other butene isomer substrate. This discrepancy will be further investigated in our future endeavors. Although the oligomerization system is quite complicated and still under debate, this catalytic mixture has been the subject of much inquiry, including a few in-depth mechanism studies. According to the conventionally accepted alkene dimerization mechanism (Cossee-Arlman or metallisation), two similar dimers (3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene and 3,4-dimethyl-2-hexene) should be theoretically produced with a certain ratio of selectivity (Fig. S4). However, we only identified 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene with 99.9 % selectivity in the experiment (Fig. S5). We also propose a possible reaction pathway for the trans-2-butene dimerization process (Fig. 5). The alkylation and ionization reactions of the desired catalyst (1) with MAO in excess, rapidly result in the formation of catalytically active species (2). The first reactive intermediate (3) of the oligomerization process is formed by the coordination and insertion of trans-2-butene into the Fe-Me bond of (2). Only even carbon olefins were detected, so we believe that metal hydrides (4) act as active center of the present Fe(II)-based catalytic systems, which were formed via β-hydride elimination of (3), and further alkene insertion yields the even carbon-number compounds. Chain transfer of oligomer units to metal also occurs during this reaction, which regenerates (4) for the further production of even carbon number α-olefins. Despite the large amount of information on the structures of hydride intermediates generated in transition metal complex activator systems, the mechanisms of their actions in the discussed processes remain open questions. The process from intermediate (4) to (12) or (14) follows the classical Cossee-Arlman mechanism, including alkene coordination, insertion, chain growth, chain transfer, and chain termination of olefins. However, in the case of trans-2-butene dimerization, there will also be chain rotation (8–9) and selective elimination of β-hydride (10–12 and 13–14). Prior to the insertion of the second trans-2-butene, at (8), chain rotation occurs to provide sufficient space for coordination of the second trans-2-butene monomer [25,26]. This may be a reason that no active performance was found for other catalysts or substrate monomers. In addition, chain transfer resulted from β-hydride elimination induced from hydrogen located on methylene to the Fe(II) metal to form the active species (4) is more favourable as a result of chain rotation. Moreover, the structure and energy of reaction intermediates and transition states are calculated by Density Functional Theory (DFT) density functional theory (from 10 to 14). The results show that the molecular model of 2-imino-1,10-phenanthroline FeCl2 (II) complexes has a lower energy barrier for β-hydride elimination to form 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene (6.21 Kcal mol−1) compared to that of 3,4-dimethyl-2-hexene (12.4 Kcal mol−1), which was consistent with the experimental result. In the present work, we prove that iron-based catalysed isomerization of alkene yielded satisfactory activity and conformational selectivity, in which the catalytic environment formed in the Fe2 complex favours β-H elimination to form terminal or α-olefin. 4 Conclusion Dimerization and oligomerization reactions are widely used to convert light olefins resulting from various processes into higher olefins that are demanded in various industrial fields. In the present work, the attention is shifting towards late transition metal iron complexes, where varying the ligand structure allows a significant influence to be exerted on the activity of trans-2-butene catalytic systems and the regio-selectivity of alkene insertion. The synthesized 2-imino-1,10-phenanthroline FeCl2 (II) complexes for oligomerization show highly catalytic performance, in which the catalyst with mono-methyl substituent exhibits maximum activity and selectivity to dimer (3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene). Nevertheless, with the variation of monomer butene isomer structures, the distinction in oligomerization performance was observed. We concluded the fact that trans-2-butene monomer insertion is followed by a rotation leading to favorable elimination of the methylene hydrogen to obtain high selectivity for the target product. The σ- and π-ligand environments of the transition metal play pivotal roles in determining the lifespan of specific active sites, which are necessary for successful alkene insertion, chain propagation, and termination. Consequently, future research demands a comprehensive approach encompassing the exploration of catalytic system properties and the experimental and theoretical analysis of structural and dynamic features of hydride intermediates. This holistic approach aims to develop robust models for reaction mechanisms and predict the properties of new promising catalytic systems. coredata.dc:description: Trans-2-butene is regularly burned as a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) component in several developing countries due to its inertness and inseparability in comparison to other butene isomers (1-butene and isobutene), resulting in low-value utilization of resource and environmental degradation. The generation of high-carbon olefins via trans-2-butene oligomerization has become one of the most effective ways for its high-value valorization. Octene is currently undersupplied via ethylene oligomerization, and its traditional crafts are costly due to separation from full-fraction α-olefins (C4-C30). In the present work, we synthesized a series of novel 2-phenyl-ketimine-1,10-phenanthroline iron complexes (Fe0-Fe9). Fe2 catalyst realizes the dimerization of trans-2-butene through homogeneous catalysis at moderate conditions (0.2 MPa, 30 °C), obtaining 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene with 99.9 % selectivity. In contrast to the reported heterogeneous catalysts, our catalytic system exhibits a considerable improvement in activity and selectivity.

coredata.dc:title: Unparalleled dimerization of trans-2-butene to 3,4-dimethyl-1-hexene on iron-based catalyst
